posts.title: â˜”ï¸ The Weather is You: Building a Kotlin Jetpack Compose Weather App with Heart
posts.description:
When life feels unpredictableâ€Šâ€”â€Šlike ulan sa tag-araw or init sa tag-ulanâ€Šâ€”â€Šsometimes, all you need is a simple reminder: â€œYou control your own weather.â€

This is exactly what I tried to build in my Kotlin Jetpack Compose side project, the Baryo Weather App. A lightweight app that detects your city, displays a playful mood icon, and reminds you to enjoy life, rain orÂ shine.

But beneath that minimalist UI? Maraming ganap. Letâ€™s walk through the tech, the structure, and the hugot behind theÂ code.

ğŸš€ ProjectÂ Summary

This app:

  • Fetches your current city and zip via the Fused Location Provider.
  • Displays one of 3 moods: sunny, rainy,Â cloudy.
  • Allows you to tap and switch between moods manually.
  • Uses Jetpack Compose + Material 3 UI + Accompanist Permissions.

ğŸ§¥ Hugot + TechÂ Stack

I wanted the UI to feel like your mood: light, changeable, and responsive. Like life, weather canâ€™t be controlledâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut we can choose how weÂ react.

â€œKung hindi mo kayang kontrolin ang ulan, magdala ka ngÂ payong.â€

Technologies used:

  • Kotlin
  • Jetpack Compose
  • Material 3 Components
  • Google LocationÂ Services
  • Accompanist Permissions

ğŸ•¹ï¸ WeatherScreen() - The Composable That Sets theÂ Mood

val weather = remember { mutableStateOf("sunny") }

You can cycle through sunny, rainy, or cloudy by tapping the screen. Each weather has a matching Icon, message, and backgroundColor.

val icon = when (weather) {
  "sunny" -> Icons.Default.WbSunny
  "rainy" -> Icons.Default.Umbrella
  "cloudy" -> Icons.Default.Cloud
  else -> Icons.Default.Help
}

This simple toggle gives the user control. Kasi minsan, kahit gloomy ang paligid, pwede kang pumili ng moodÂ mo.

ğŸ“ Location Magic with fetchLocation()

val (fetchedCity, fetchedZip) = fetchLocation(context)

Weâ€™re using Googleâ€™s FusedLocationProviderClient to get precise GPS data. Then Geocoder converts coordinates into a city name and postalÂ code.

val addresses = geocoder.getFromLocation(lat, long, 1)

This makes the app feel yours. ItÂ says:

â€œHey, youâ€™re in [CITY], and that matters.â€

No backend needed. Just native Android APIs and Kotlin coroutines for async handling.

ğŸš« Permission Drama (Handled Gracefully)

Using accompanist-permissions, we check and request ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION:

val permissionState = rememberPermissionState(Manifest.permission.ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION)

It reacts based on whether the user grants or denies permission. Ganda ng integration. No ugly dialogs orÂ crashes.

ğŸ¨ Material You UIâ€Šâ€”â€ŠWith SoftÂ Corners

Card(
  shape = RoundedCornerShape(20.dp),
  colors = CardDefaults.cardColors(containerColor = Color.White.copy(alpha = 0.8f))
)

The UI adapts to the current weather. Each Card displays an icon, a message, and your location. Everything centers in the middle using Box(contentAlignment = Alignment.Center).

â€œEven when life feels off-center, your UIâ€Šâ€”â€Šand your selfâ€Šâ€”â€Šcan stay centered.â€

ğŸš€ FutureÂ Plans

  • Hook up real-time data from OpenWeatherMap API
  • Offline cache of last fetchedÂ city
  • Show mood based on real weather, not justÂ tap

ğŸ™ FinalÂ Thoughts

This was a short project with a simple goal: remind the user that they can bring sunshine wherever they go. With Kotlin and Jetpack Compose, I could move fast, build cleanly, and inject a littleÂ heart.

Try it. Modify it. Fork it. Build yourÂ version.

Because in the end, your weather doesnâ€™t define you. You define yourÂ weather.

âœ¨ GitHub Repo: https://github.com/arnelirobles/WeatherApp

Follow for more dev stories with heart: medium.com/@baryodev

#AndroidDev #JetpackCompose #BaryoDev #KotlinWithHugot

P.S. I just whipped this up before sleeping, so itâ€™s not yet complete. Will update with more features and polish soon.Â ğŸ›Œ

posts.description:
Letâ€™s face itâ€Šâ€”â€Šsometimes life feels like a coin toss. ğŸŒ€ One moment youâ€™re winning in life ğŸ†, the next, youâ€™re wondering why you even got out of bed ğŸ˜µ. Gani man, kabudlay guid sang kabuhi, pero sige lang, go pa rin (Translation: Even so, life is really hard, but we keep going anyway.Â ğŸ’ª)

Recently, I built a simple browser-based game called Flip Coin Game. Just two buttons: Heads or Tails. ğŸ‘†ğŸ² Click, wait, tapos boomâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou either win or lose. Thatâ€™s it. No bosses to beat ğŸ‘¹, no dragons to slay ğŸ‰, no microtransactions ğŸ’¸ (because di tayo ganâ€™unâ€Šâ€”â€Šweâ€™re not likeÂ that).

ğŸ›  How It Works (Spoiler Alert: Itâ€™s Riggedâ€¦ by Math, Not Feelings)

The logic is super straightforward. You choose: Heads ğŸŸ¡ or Tails âšª. The app flips a virtual coin (using Math.random()), and tells you if you won ğŸ‰ or lostÂ ğŸ˜….

Each result is saved in a game history ğŸ“œ with pagination âªâ©â€Šâ€”â€Šso yes, pwede kang bumalik sa mga panalo mo, parang sa mga good memories ğŸ¥¹
(Translation: You can go back to your victories, like reminiscing the goodÂ times.)

It alsoÂ tracks:

  • ğŸ® GamesÂ Played
  • ğŸ… GamesÂ Won

Perfect for those statistikang-hugot momentsÂ like:

â€œOut of 50 tries, I only won 20â€¦ ganito rin pala ang love life ko. One-sided pa rin. ğŸ’”â€
(Translation:Â â€¦just like my love life. Still one-sided.)

And the best part? ğŸ§  It uses localStorage para di mawawala ang progress mo... unless lumipas na ang 24 hours â³â€”then it resets itself ğŸ—‘.
(Translation: so your progress doesnâ€™t disappear... unless 24 hours have passed.)
Why? Kasi just like our past mistakesâ€”kailangan din i-let go after a while. ğŸ˜Œ
(Translation: Because, just like past mistakesâ€”we also need to let them go eventually.)

ğŸ¤“ Bakit Ko â€˜To Ginawa? (Why Did I MakeÂ This?)

I made this for funâ€Šâ€”â€Šand for learning. ğŸ§ª

I wanted a game that felt light but meaningful. Something na kahit sinong taga-barangay pwedeng laruin ğŸ§‘â€ğŸŒ¾
(Translation: Something anyone from the village canÂ play.)

No installs, no app stores. Just simple logic, design, andÂ love.

Itâ€™s also a great way to learn basic JavaScript:

  • ğŸ”„ DOM Manipulation
  • ğŸ’¡ Conditional Logic
  • ğŸ’¾ LocalÂ Storage
  • ğŸ“‘ Pagination

And sometimes, we all need something na hindi toxic.
(Translation: Something thatâ€™s not emotionally draining.)

In this game, wala kang kailangang patunayan.
(Translation: You donâ€™t have anything to prove.)
You just click, smile, maybe lose, then try again.Â ğŸ˜„

ğŸ’­ The Hidden Lesson in a CoinÂ Flip

At first glance, this game looks like laro lang ğŸ•¹ (just a game).
But behind the clicks is something real.Â ğŸ­

Life is filled with coin flipsâ€Šâ€”â€Šjob interviews ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’¼, love confessions ğŸ’Œ, startup pitches ğŸ’», parenting decisions ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ‘§. Sometimes you win. Sometimes you donâ€™t. But just like this game, ang importante, sumubok ka pa rin. âœ… (Translation: what matters most is that you stillÂ tried.)

You clicked. You chose. You participated.

And heyâ€Šâ€”â€Škahit hindi ka palaging panalo, at least may history ka na sumubok ka. ğŸ“šğŸ’ª
(Translation: even if you didnâ€™t always win, at least you have proof that youÂ tried.)

Gani sa kabuhi, indi pag-isipon ang resulta lang. Tani, isipon mo man kung paano ka nagsikap, nagdesisyon, kag nagbago. ğŸŒ±
(Translation: In life, donâ€™t just focus on the result. Think also about how you tried, made decisions, and changed.)

Kung gusto mong silipin kung paano gumagana ang tadhanaâ€¦ este, coin flip logic koâ€Šâ€”â€Šnasa loob lang ng folder na â€˜yan. ğŸ˜…
(Translation: If you want to see how fateâ€Šâ€”â€Šuhm, I mean, the coin flip logicâ€Šâ€”â€Šworks, itâ€™s just inside thatÂ folder.)

https://github.com/arnelirobles/CoinFlip

ğŸ›  BuiltÂ with:

  • HTML ğŸ§±

âš ï¸ Warning: Pang-developers lang â€˜toâ€Šâ€”â€Šmedyo may command line drama.
(Translation: This is for people who know how to codeâ€Šâ€”â€Šthereâ€™s a bit of command line drama involved.)

âœ… Steps to deploy usingÂ Surge:

Install Surge globally
ğŸ–¥ï¸ Open your terminal or commandÂ prompt:

npm install --global surge

Go to your project folder
Example:

cd path/to/CoinFlip

Deploy!
JustÂ type:

surge

It will askÂ for:

  • Your emailÂ ğŸ“§
  • Your desired subdomain (e.g., coinflip.surge.sh) ğŸŒ

Done! ğŸ‰
Youâ€™ll get a live link like:
https://coinflip.surge.sh â€“ share it, blog it, brag aÂ bit.

And if youâ€™re coding your own games or apps, rememberâ€Šâ€”â€Šokay lang mag-start sa simple. (Translation: Itâ€™s totally okay to start with something simple.)
One line of code today, one realization tomorrow.

ğŸª™ Heads or tails? Doesnâ€™t matter. At least ikaw ang pumindot. ğŸ”˜

posts.title: Lotto Predictor: Built for Fun, Powered by Curiosity
posts.description:
In the small town where I grew up, people would gather around sari-sari stores and radio sets during PCSO lotto announcements. Some would whisper their birthdays, anniversaries, even house numbersâ€Šâ€”â€Šhoping their â€œluckyâ€ combinations would hit. That memory stuck withÂ me.

Fast forward to today, Iâ€™m a software developerâ€Šâ€”â€Šstill curious, still hoping. So I thought, â€œWhy not build a simple lotto predictor?â€ Not to hack fate. Not to get rich. But just forÂ fun.

This project is a mix of tech, randomness, and a bit of swerte. And noâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI donâ€™t claim to predict winning numbers. This tool is here to entertain and maybe make youÂ smile.

ğŸ› ï¸ How ItÂ Works

This app does two mainÂ things:

  1. Scrapes actual PCSO 6/45 lotto results for 2022 and 2023 using HtmlAgilityPack
  2. Generates 30 daysâ€™ worth of random lotto predictions, following the same 6-numberÂ format

ğŸ“¦ The Code (Explained Simply)

Step 1: Define theÂ Model

public class LotteryResult
{
    public DateTime DrawDate { get; set; }
    public int[] WinningNumbers { get; set; }
    public decimal JackpotPrize { get; set; }
}

This class stores the draw date, the 6 winning numbers, and the jackpotÂ prize.

Step 2: Scrape Historical Results

We use HttpClient and HtmlAgilityPack to extract HTML from the official PCSOÂ website:

var html = await httpClient.GetStringAsync(url);
var htmlDocument = new HtmlDocument();
htmlDocument.LoadHtml(html);

We locate the table containing lottoÂ results:

var table = htmlDocument.DocumentNode.SelectSingleNode("//figure[contains(@class, 'wp-block-table')]/table");

Then, we parse each row to extract the date, winning numbers (split by dash), and jackpot value (in pesos). We wrap this logic in a helperÂ method:

public static async Task<List<LotteryResult>> ExtractLotteryResults(string url)

It gracefully skips errors and handles rows with missingÂ data.

Step 3: Print AllÂ Results

foreach (var result in lotteryResults.OrderBy(c => c.DrawDate))
{
    Console.WriteLine($"Draw Date: {result.DrawDate.Date}, Winning Numbers: {string.Join(", ", result.WinningNumbers)}, Jackpot Prize (Php): {result.JackpotPrize}");
}

This outputs a full summary of all past draws in readableÂ format.

Step 4: Predict 30 Daysâ€™ Worth of Random Combinations

Hereâ€™s where the â€œpredictionâ€ comes in. We use a simple helper to generate 6 unique, random numbers within the known range:CopyEdit

public static int[] GenerateRandomCombination(int minValue, int maxValue, int count)
{
    var numbers = new int[count];
    for (int i = 0; i < count; i++)
    {
        int randomNumber;
        do
        {
            randomNumber = random.Next(minValue, maxValue + 1);
        } while (Array.IndexOf(numbers, randomNumber) != -1);
        numbers[i] = randomNumber;
    }
    Array.Sort(numbers);
    return numbers;
}

We loop this 30 times to simulate a monthâ€™s worth of predictions:

for (int i = 0; i < days; i++)
{
    var randomCombination = LotteryPredictor.GenerateRandomCombination(minValue, maxValue, numberCount);
    Console.WriteLine($"Day {i + 1}: {string.Join(", ", randomCombination)}");
}

ğŸ¯ Why I BuiltÂ This

Honestly? I just wanted to have fun. To see if I could blend data, randomness, and childhood nostalgia into something functionalâ€Šâ€”â€ŠyetÂ playful.

I believe in effort.
